newsitem.title: USA: Oracle shares fall after earnings.
newsitem.headline: Oracle shares fall after earnings.

text.p: Oracle Corp shares fell as much as 6.1 percent Wednesday after the software company's earnings failed to match Wall Street's more optimistic forecasts.

"They had a fine quarter but they didn't blow out the numbers," said Joe Farley, a software analyst at investment bank UBS Securities in New York. "A lot of times when tech stocks don't blow their numbers out, they get a backlash."
After the market closed Tuesday, Oracle, the world's second-biggest software company, said its fiscal fourth quarter earnings rose 35 percent from a year earlier, to $359.9 million, or $0.54 a share.
That matched Wall Street's consensus forecast, according to First Call, but fell short of some investors' expectations.
Oracle shares were down 2-3/4 at 50-1/2. Earlier, the shares traded as low as 50.
In recent days, talk of huge contracts for Oracle's database and manufacturing software had boosted the stock, analysts said.
Oracle executives would not discuss particular contracts but said they had plenty of business lined up heading to the first fiscal quarter.
The optimistic outlook, however, was overshadowed by growing concerns about flagging revenue in the technology business.
Yesterday, disk-drive maker Seagate Technology Inc and PC company Gateway 2000 Inc said their quarterly earnings will be less than expected because of weak sales.
